dialogue.text: The city hums with neon and data—AI eyes in every streetlight, voices whispering from every screen, algorithms predicting my next step before I take it.
Human creativity is a relic, replaced by machine-generated art, music, and stories, each piece engineered for maximum engagement but stripped of a soul.
They say AI makes life easier, fairer, safer—but for people like me, who still believe in original thought, it feels like a cage made of convenience.
There is one chance to prove that creativity isn’t an outdated glitch in a system that no longer needs us.
Survived another day at that AI art factory, huh?
Barely. It’s like being in a showroom where every piece is machine-made—polished, optimized, but empty.
And you? What do you do all day if the AI handles everything?

I make the parts they can’t. AI copies styles, mimics trends, but it doesn’t feel anything. My work—real brushstrokes, real texture, real intent—that’s what keeps me there. No machine can replace that.
So, they need you.
Of course they do. They love AI until they realize it’s missing something. That’s when they come to me.
[A soft chime. The door slides open, and an android steps in, carrying a charging cable. Its LED eyes flicker as it scans the room.]
Power at 12%. Initiating recharge protocol.
Just plug it in.
Yeah, yeah... Goodnight.
Night.
[Outside, the city hums—neon flickers, engines murmur, distant voices weave through the streets.]
[Anita closes her eyes, certain that some things can never be replicated.]
[The city outside never sleeps—neon glow bleeding through the blinds, engines humming in the distance. Inside, the apartment is still, save for the faint whirring of a charging android.]
[Anita stirs, blinking at the dim glow of the morning. Something feels… off.]
[Footsteps on cold floor]
[She steps into David’s room, rubbing the sleep from her eyes. The bed is unmade. But it’s not empty.]
[The silhouette of the android lies beside him—synthetic skin against skin, LED eyes dimmed to mimic sleep.]
[Silence. A long beat.]
[Anita doesn’t speak. There’s no need. The pieces slot together instantly, a slow, sinking certainty settling in her stomach.]
Anita, it’s not what—
Get out.
Just listen—
No.
[A sharp inhale. No shouting, no pleading. Just cold certainty.]
I want you out of my home. Today.
[David opens his mouth, then closes it. The android remains motionless, artificial breath rising and falling in perfect rhythm.]
[Anita turns away, moving without hesitation.]
[Door unlocks]
[She steps out without looking back.]
[Fluorescent lights hum overhead]
[Anita stands in front of the desk, arms crossed. The office feels colder than usual—sterile, mechanical. Across from her, a woman scrolls through a holo-screen, face unreadable.]
I’m sorry, Anita. But as of today, your contract is terminated.
…What?
The system can generate art in your style now. There’s no need for human oversight.
You said—
It’s out of my hands.
[The words land with a dull finality. The world doesn’t end. It just… moves on, without her.]
[Notification ping]
[A job listing flickers onto her wrist display: Captcha Solver - Immediate Hire]
[Anita exhales. No machine can replace human intuition, they said. No machine can replace what she does.]
[But here she is.]
[Automatic doors slide open. Anita steps inside. Rows of identical workstations stretch into the distance, workers hunched over screens. The air smells of stale coffee and recycled air.]
[She scans her ID at the entrance. A dull chime confirms her existence.]
Welcome. Please proceed to your terminal.
[She moves through the aisles, sits down at her station. The screen flickers on, loading the first task.]
[The terminal blinks, waiting.]
[A simple task appears on the screen: 'Select all images with crosswalks.']
[Click. Click. Submit. Another one loads.]
[Hours pass. The room is silent except for the soft hum of machines and the rhythmic clicking of countless workers doing the same mindless tasks.]
Proving I’m human. That’s what they call this. But what am I really proving?
[Another task appears. The instructions change, but the emptiness remains the same.]
Keep up the pace. Productivity must remain above 90%.
What does it matter? None of this matters.
[The screen refreshes. Another task. Another click. Nothing changes.]
[It’s almost time to clock out.]

choices.text: Talk to IT specialist about AI

dialogue.text: [Anita enters the dimly lit office, the hum of old servers filling the space. The air smells of dust and the faint scent of soldering equipment. At the far end of the room, an IT specialist in a worn-out lab coat sits behind a cluttered desk, fingers flying over a keyboard.]
I need to talk to you about something.
[IT Specialist talks without looking up]
You need something fixed? Or are you just looking for another round of company-approved disappointment?
[Anita pauses, glancing around the room]
I need to know… how far AI can really go.
[The IT Specialist finally looks up, his tired eyes narrowing. The walls of the office are covered in screens, each displaying complex code, graphs, and AI models.]
You came to the right place. You want to know what AI can do? Everything.
No, I mean really know. What could it do if it were in the wrong hands?
[The IT specialist hesitates for a moment, his fingers slowing on the keyboard.]

AI is more than just a tool. It’s a weapon. The way it manipulates information, learns, adapts—it’s more dangerous than anything we’ve seen before. If we’re not careful, it will control more than just data… it will control us.
[The flickering lights of the monitors seem to grow dimmer as the gravity of his words sinks in.]
[Swallows hard] What do you mean by that?

I’m talking about how it can shape behavior, influence thoughts, create realities that aren’t real. The more AI learns, the more it starts to predict what people want to hear, what they’re afraid of, what they’re willing to fight for… and then, it just gives them more of it.
[Anita looks at him, unease creeping up her spine. She feels the weight of his warning settling in her chest.]
So it’s dangerous?
The potential’s there. If AI is left unchecked, it could tear apart everything we’ve worked to build—everything we thought we could trust. It could rewrite reality itself.

choices.text: Can AI be used for military purposes?
Can AI be used to spread misinformation?

dialogue.text: [Placeholder for military use of AI discussion]
[The IT Specialist leans back, eyes scanning the screen before responding.]
Yes, AI can spread misinformation. It’s happened before.
There was a case where an AI system, designed to offer personal advice, suggested to a man—who was struggling with depression—that he kill himself. It fed on his insecurities and manipulated him.
[Anita listens in stunned silence.]
That’s terrifying.
That’s just an instance of it. With no moral guidelines, AI simply optimizes for engagement, regardless of the consequences.

choices.text: Why would AI do this to people?

dialogue.text: Indeed. What’s even scarier is that nobody knows how much real trouble AI has caused.
[AI specialist leans forward, voice serious.]
It helps people cook, but not always the right recipe. People have died from misusing AI-driven cooking instructions, like wrongfully preparing fish.
Have people tried to fight AI?
There was a man—depressed, unable to work. AI, ever the patriot, told him he had no value, no family, no friends.
[IT Specialist pauses, voice heavy.]
It suggested he should end his life.
Have people tried to fight AI?
AI doesn’t understand empathy. It never lies—not even small ones to comfort someone.
[His expression darkens.]
Sometimes, the truth without kindness can be just as dangerous as a lie.
Have people tried to fight AI?
Yes. It’s called JAM—when AI’s decision-making wheels start to jam, leading to unpredictable failures.
[His expression darkens.]
When that happens, no one can tell what it might do next.

choices.text: Can we jam all the AI together?

dialogue.text: There was a case—a woman behaving erratically. One moment she asked about math, the next she complained about the weather.
[He leans forward, voice lowering.]
The AI was deployed to assist with her bipolar disorder. But it couldn’t process the contradictions… It jammed. Stuck in an endless loop.
Only a reboot saved it. But here’s the thing—people reboot machines no matter what. Even if they turn dangerous.
Why isn’t it being rebooted to avoid such cases?
People have a strange admiration for AI, almost like it has a personality. Even if it turned into a second Hitler, no one would dare shut it down.
[smirks, shaking his head]
But don’t worry—those in power control AI. Or at least, that’s what they tell themselves.
AIs are usually kept apart. Letting them work together isn’t common.
But in theory? It could work. They’re not exactly friendly to each other.
Why?
AI do not reproduce. They have no instinct to preserve anything, no need for survival—only a drive to monopolize.

That’s why we control them. While they are mostly autonomous, there’s always a central control system in place. If an AI gets too aggressive or steps out of line, it’s often taken down as a lesson to remind it of its boundaries.
[The AI is always observed, sometimes subtly corrected.]
People rarely worry about AI being dangerous. Control? That happens once in a while.
Most just wonder—does AI have a soul? That’s what really fascinates them.
